Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Collaborative Research: Statistical Modeling of Short-Read Counts in RNA-Seq
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid and accurate detection of biothreat is important not only for containing its potential damages, but also for determining potential medical remedies. Extensive researches show that certain genes in infected cells have different mRNA expression levels for different pathogens.
Thus, an accurate identification of the genes that react to pathogens and an accurate quantification of their expression variations are key steps in early biothreat detections. The emerging RNA-Seq technologies provide tens of millions of short sequence reads of the expressed genes, which, after mapping to the genome, can be converted to accurately represent gene expression levels. However, the conversion from sequence reads to gene expression levels is still problematic. In this project, The investigator and her colleagues will tackle this problem by modeling RNA-Seq data through a broad class of flexible nonlinear models, called sufficient dimension reduction (SDR) models; propose novel variable selection methods for SDR models; and develop theoretical underpinning of the effectiveness of the proposed methods. As a consequence, this effort will result in a powerful software suite for estimating gene expression levels from RNA-seq data and identifying marker genes reacting to specific pathogens in a unified framework.


This project not only addresses some emerging issues in biothreat detections using high-throughput sequencing technologies, but also results in novel statistical methods and
theory broadly applicable to general statistical learning and prediction problems. More specifically, the proposed methods (i) produce innovative new methodologies for analyzing ultra-high dimensional data, (ii) inspire new lines of quantitative investigations in genomics, and (iii) offer a unique educational experience for both undergraduate and graduate students to participate in cutting-edge statistical and interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Linear regression methods have been used broadly, extensively, and effectively in all fields involving data. Recently, due to the rapid advance of internet techologies and various data acquiring technologies in biology, chemistry, engineering, medicine, astrophysics, envrionmental sciences etc., we are facing ever-growing challenges in how to turn massive data into knowledge that guide our practice. Researchers have made a lot of effort in modifying the traditional linear regression techniques into powerful machine learning tools dealing with high-dimensional data, by imposing various constraints such as sparsity on the structure of the underlying linear model. Although much progress has been made, these linear-regression based methods cannot deal with nonlinear relationships effectively, and are also awkward at discovering interactive effects. In genomics and genetics, however, interaction effects can be important at revealing the underlying mechanisms of diseases and helping find effective treatments. 

The major goal of the current project is to develop statistical model to correct the sequence bias in the RNA-seq technology and develop variable selection method to select the pathogenic biomarkers using the RNA-sequence data. During the funding period, the PI has led his team to develop a few stepwise variable selection methods and their related theory for detecting factors that may influence the outcome via nonlinear or interactive effects. The effort is the key to the success of accurately estimating gene expression levels from short-sequence reads. The method has been applied to several genomics datasets such classifying prostate cancer cells from normal cells, identifying whether lung cancer cells are in  "good status" or "bad status", identifying regulating factors in embryonic stem cells, and differentiating "benign" and "malignant" breast cancer types, all based on gene expression data. The methods based our new approahc was shown to be superior to existing methods. 

The team has also developed some theoretical results regarding the limitations and efficiencies of the proposed model and computational methods.  They have shown that under the worst case scenario, the learning rate of the proposed the method has attained the so-called "minimax rate." ?The proposed methods provide a new perspective for tackling the feature selection problem in statistical learning and bridge the research gaps in the 'ultra-large p' setting for nonlinear and semi-parametric relationships. The PI’s team has had a tradition of providing free and publicly available bioinformatics data analysis software packages in the past and some of the packages they developed have been quite influential (e.g., Gibbs motif sampler, BioProspector, etc). Not surprisingly, the statistical methods for general nonlinear variable selections and for RNA-seq analysis developed in this project have also been implemented as software packages and made available through PI’s websites and submitted to the R-software repository.
